title: Coding Provenance Workshop. First Edition
text:
This workshop explores the intersection between provenance studies and computational techniques, bringing together a selected cohort of scholars, curators, and practitioners to explore digital approaches, data modeling, computational analysis, and data visualization.

From 18 to 21 December 2025 — Leuphana University
Room C.40.606, Seminarraum, Main Building at Leuphana University


Sessions

Optical Character Recognition
Knowledge Design. Data Models, Ontologies & Controlled Vocabularies
Learning How to Code
From Raw Text to Structured Data
Data Preprocessing, Analysis, and a New World of Research Questions

Network Analysis


Data Viusalization
Bibliography & other Resources

title: Sample Provenance Datasets
text:
Knoedler Stockbooks



Art Institute of Chicago

About the Dataset
This dataset compiles provenance records from the Art Institute of Chicago’s online collection database.
It includes artworks such as paintings, sculptures, prints, drawings, and decorative arts.
In the original API, provenance information appears as free text. For the purposes of this workshop, this material has been transformed into structured provenance events, where each event includes one or more involved parties (people, families, institutions) and other semantic components. The information of all provenance statements remains exactly as provided by the Art Institute of Chicago — no corrections, additions, or interpretative changes have been introduced.
API — Art Institute of Chicago
Art Institute of Chicago Provenance Dataset



Documentation of Variables
(click to expand each section)






Artwork-Level Variables





These fields sit at the top level of each JSON object.








Variable
Type
Description




id
Integer
Internal numeric identifier for each artwork (unique).


title
String
Public title of the work.


alt_titles
String or array, nullable
Alternative titles when available.


main_reference_number
String
Accession/inventory number.


date_start
Integer
Earliest possible creation year (BCE negative, CE positive).


date_end
Integer
Latest possible creation year.


artist_display
String
Display text describing maker/culture/origin.


place_of_origin
String
Normalized place name extracted from the record.


dimensions
String
Free-text measurements.


medium_display
String
Materials and techniques.


inscriptions
String, nullable
Description or transcription of inscriptions.


credit_line
String
How the work entered the collection (gift, purchase, etc.).


provenance_text
String
Narrative provenance as written by AIC curators.


events_structured
Array
Parsed provenance events derived from the narrative.












Provenance Event-Level Variables





Each entry in events_structured represents a structured provenance fragment.








Variable
Type
Description




event
String
Event identifier (e.g., “event_1”). Groups components belonging to the same ownership step.


value
String
Extracted fragment referring to a person, method, date, place, etc.


type
Array of strings
Semantic labels defining the nature of value. May include:




• Person — Named individual




• Party — Any owner (person, family, institution)




• Group — Collective/institutional actor




• Receiver — Party acquiring the work




• Method — How the object changed hands (“sold”, “given”)




• Time — Specific dates or years




• Vagueness — Uncertain expressions (“by 1938”)




• Name — Explicit name tag (overlaps with Person/Party)

title: Our Mission and Vision & Organizers
text:
The workshop
This workshop is a collaboration between the Provenance Lab and the Getty Provenance Index.
After decades working as provenance and art history researchers, we have witnessed the field changing and evolving in many different ways. We believe that the intersection between computational techniques and provenance studies can not only reveal patterns, structures, and dynamics that were hard to uncover through close reading, but also lead us to new research questions that were previously impossible to answer or to know.
Our aim with this workshop is to equip researchers and practitioners with concrete skills and to introduce them to methodologies that can inspire new policies, practices, and analytical approaches within their institutions or individual research projects. We believe that interdisciplinary collaboration, between art historians, provenance researchers, museum professionals, computer scientists, and digital humanities specialists, is essential. However, for these collaborations to be fair, productive, and balanced, all participants need a shared understanding of what is possible, how different methods work, and what their limitations are.
This workshop is designed as a first encounter with key theories, methods, techniques, and tools. Our goal is to open a conversation, spark critical thinking, and lay the groundwork for a collaborative effort that will continue to grow beyond these sessions.



Organizers and Instructors




Bárbara Romero Ferrón


Provenance Lab, Leuphana University of Lüneburg





Lynn Rother


Provenance Lab, Leuphana University of Lüneburg





Giulia Taurino
